STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 26, 2024
Aprille Sutton
Child & Family Services of Northwestern Michigan
3785 Veterans Dr,
Traverse City, MI, 49684-4516
Re: License #: CB280201037
Dear Ms. Sutton:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
February 29, 2024 Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (e) A dental examination must be
completed within 3 months before entry
into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after entry
into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care
under 1 year of age must have an initial
dental exam within 3 months of his or
her first birthday.
Eight foster care files were reveiwed. One of eight files documented a late dental
exam.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
0 3/1/2023 Renewal, CAP approved 03/10/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
2

• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every
90 calendar days thereafter.
Eight files and 27 services plans were reviewed. Two of 27 service plans were
completed late.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Eight files were reviewed. Five of eight files each had a service plan period where a
case reassessment FTM was not held.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
03/18/2022 Interim, CAP approved 04/14/2022.
03/9/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 04/05/2021.
0 3/1/2023 Renewal, CAP approved 03/10/2023.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker.
• Supervisor.
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart.
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures
3

pages into the electronic case record within 30 days
of the report date.
Eight files and 27 treatment plans were reviewed. Nine of 27 treatment plans
had treatment plans that were signed more than thirty days from the date of the
service plan. Therefore, the signature pages were not uploaded into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
03/18/2022 Interim, CAP approved 04/14/2022.
03/9/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 04/05/2021.
03/1/2023 Renewal, CAP approved 03/10/2023.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 400.12415 (a) Incident reports. Discussed the requirement that incidents
reports are to be submitted to the consultant. Only those incidents named
under the rule are to be submitted.
• DCWL review of CAPS. The agency was informed that starting January 1,
2024, interim and renewal audit CAP's will be reviewed with the agency at
three months and six months. The assigned Consultant for the agency will
work with the agency in conducting CAP reviews. This process for special
investigation CAP reviews was implemented previously in 2022.
• Timely uploading of documents. It was recommended that the agency upload
documents such as the DHS-1105 in a timelier manner. A number of
documents were completed but not uploaded at the time of the audit.
• The agency is opening a ILP program. Direction was provided for the agency
to document that youth received the ILP program statement, (R 400.12502),
as well as the ILP policies, (R 400.12503.). It was also recommended for the
agency to clearly document that a youth under consideration for the program
is meeting eligibility requirements, (R 400.12504).
V. CONSULTATION
• Consultation was not requested or required at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
4

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) on April 3,
2023. The CAP was in response to those violations established during the renewal
inspection completed on March 1, 2023. The violations established during the
renewal inspection are as follows:
1. FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans.
2. FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
3. R 400. 12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
4. R 400.12413 Medical and dental policy
5. R 400.12510 Independent living contract
6. R 400.12708 Child Evaluation
7. FOM-06H Case Contacts.
The current interim inspection established repeat violations of FOM 722-08D,
FOM 722-06B, and R 400.12413. The agency CAP was successful in preventing
repeat violations of R 400.12510, R 400.12708 and FOM 722-06H. Additional
corrective planning will be completed to address the repeated violations.
The agency submitted an approved corrective action plan on March 10, 2023, in
response to a violation established during special investigation 2023C000066
completed on March 3, 2023.The violation established during the special
investigation is as follows:
1. R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
The corrective action plan was successful in preventing a repeat violation of the
rule.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators annual assessment was reviewed. The assessment was
thorough and detailed agency efforts to comply with their corrective action plan.
The assessment identified barriers that the agency encountered during the year
which included the hiring and training of four new foster care workers. The
assessment also identified a number of staff absences due to contagious
respiratory infections. The assessment further noted that MISACWIS and CWLM
are often problematic and time consuming to work with.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no noted concerns.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported feeling they have supportive, competent supervision.
They also reported they feel they are part of a solid team, workers support each
other and work together.
5

Youth were not interviewed by the consultant.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is a modern, well equipped and maintained building in Traverse City.
The walk through established that CHRI documents are stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst identified one safety concern during her visits to the homes. The
safety alert is as follows:
Safety Alert 1. The safety alert, generated on December 18, 2023, and sent to the
agency on December 19, 2023, identified missing a smoke alarm near a child's
bedroom. An agency staff visited the home on December 19, 2023, and an alarm
was installed. Photos of the alarm were provided and uploaded in CWLM.
The CPA Analyst noted during the entrance meeting that foster parents and relatives
interviewed reported feeling supported by the agency and liked the workers that are
assigned to their homes.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
March 21, 2024
________________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
